API Documentation¶

Parameters¶

class statnight.parameters.Observable(name, range)[source]¶

Class for physics observables.

Arguments:

  • name a string
  • range a tuple with lower and upper limits of the range
Example:
obs = Observable(name=”x”, range=(0,100))
class statnight.parameters.Variable(name, range, initvalue: (<class 'int'>, <class 'float'>) = -1.0, initstep: (<class 'int'>, <class 'float'>) = -1.0, constraint: (<class 'int'>, <class 'float'>) = None)[source]¶

Class for variable paramaters.

Arguments:

  • name a string
  • value a tuple with lower and upper limits of the range
  • initvalue (optionnal). a number (int/float) inside the range
  • initstep (optionnal). a number (int/float) lower than the

range size - constraint (optionnal). a function with one argument that returns a number (int/float)

Examples:
var = (name=”sigma”, range=(0, 5)) var = (name=”sigma”, range=(0, 5), initvalue=2.5, initstep=0.1) var = (name=”sigma”, range=(0, 5), constraint= lambda x: (x-2)**2
tominuit()[source]¶

Returns a dictionnary of parameters for iminuit.

class statnight.parameters.Constant(name, value: (<class 'int'>, <class 'float'>))[source]¶

Class for constant paramaters:

Arguments:

  • name a string
  • value a number (int/float)
Example:
const = Constant(name=”mu”, value=”1.2”)
tominuit()[source]¶

Returns a dictionnary of parameters for iminuit.

Model¶

class statnight.model.Model(pdf, observables=[], variables=[], ext_pars=[])[source]¶

Class for model definition.

Arguments:

  • pdf callable object. Probability density function (pdf) of the model.
  • observables (optional). List of statnight.parameters.Observable.
  • variables (optional). List statnight.parameters.Variable.
  • ext_pars (optional). List of name (str) of the extended parameters of the model.
pdf()¶

Returns the probability density function of the model.

parameters()¶

Returns the parameters, from the pdf, of the model.

observables()¶

Returns the observables of the model.

add_obs(observables)[source]¶

Add observables to the model.

Arguments:

-observables an/a list of statnight.parameters.Observable.
variables()¶

Returns the variables of the model.

add_vars(variables)[source]¶

Add variables to the model.

Arguments:

-variables an/a list of statnight.parameters.Variable.
__getitem__(name)[source]¶

Get the parameter with name.

Arguments:

-name str, name of the parameter.
ext_pars()¶

Returns the extended parameters of the model.

add_ext_pars(ext_pars)[source]¶

Add extended parameters to the model.

Arguments:

-ext_pars a list of strings.
extended()¶

Returns True is the model has extended parameters, else False.

create_hypothesis(pois={})[source]¶

Create an Hypothesis from the model.

Arguments:

-pois dictionnary with name of parameters of interest as keys and their values as values.
class statnight.model.Hypothesis(model, pois={})[source]¶

Class for statiscal hypothesis definition.

Arguments:

  • model a statnight.model.Model.
  • pois (optional). Dictionnary of parameters of interest names in

the keys and their values in the values.

pois()¶

Returns the parameters of interest.

poinames()¶

Returns the parameters of interest names.

poivalues()¶

Returns the parameters of interest values.

getpoi(name)[source]¶

Returns the parameter of interest with a given name.

Arguments:

  • name a string.
model()¶

Returns the model used to create this hypothesis.

nuis()¶

Returns the nuisance parameters.

nuisnames()¶

Returns the nuisance parameters names.

summary()[source]¶

Print a summary of this hypothesis.

Asymptotic calculator¶

class statnight.calculators.asymptotic_calculator.AsymptoticCalculator(null_hypothesis, alt_hypothesis, data, qtilde=False, onesided=True, onesideddiscovery=False, CLs=True)[source]¶

Class for for asymptotic calculators. Can be used only with one parameter of interest.

See G. Cowan, K. Cranmer, E. Gross and O. Vitells: Asymptotic formulae for likelihood- based tests of new physics. Eur. Phys. J., C71:1–19, 2011

Arguments:

  • null_hypothesis a statnight.model.Hypothesis representing the null hypothesis of the test.
  • null_hypothesis a statnight.model.Hypothesis representing the alterrnative hypothesis of the test.
  • data a numpy array. The data on which the hypothesis is tested.
  • qtilde bool (optionnal). Set the test statistic to qtilde default False.
  • onesided bool (optionnal). Set the test statistic for one sided upper limit. default True.
  • onesideddiscovery bool (optionnal). Set the test statistic for one sided discovery. default False.
  • CLs bool (optionnal). Use CLs for computing upper limit. default True.
qtilde()¶

Returrns True if qtilde test statistic is used, False if not.

onesided()¶

Returrns True if a one sided test statistic is used, False if not.

onesideddiscovery()¶

Returrns True if a one sided test statistic for discovery is used, False if not.

CLs()¶

Returrns True if CLs is used, False if not.

bestfitpoi()¶

Returns the best fit value of the parameter of interest.

pvalues()[source]¶

Returns p-values scanned for the values of the parameters of interest in the null hypothesis.

result(alpha=0.05, printlevel=1)[source]¶

Returns the result of the hypothesis test.

Arguments:
  • alpha confidence level. default 0.05
upperlimit(alpha=0.05, printlevel=1)[source]¶

Returns the upper limit of the parameter of interest.

Arguments:
  • alpha (optionnal) confidence level. default 0.05
plot(alpha=0.05, ax=None, show=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot the pvalues obtained with CLsb/CLb/CLs, and using the asimov datasets (median p_value, +bands), scanned for the different values of the parameter of interest.

Arguments:
  • alpha (optionnal) confidence level. default 0.05
  • ax (optionnal) matplotlib axis
  • show (optionnal) show the plot. default True.
